data.text: Index
Appendix 1 Acute Oncology Service Referral Form
Appendix 2 Acute Oncology Referral Pathway

Appendix 3 Acute Oncology presentations suitable for AOS referral Appendix 4 7 Day Acute Oncology Fast Track Clinic Referral Form Appendix 5 7 Day Acute Oncology Fast Track ED Referral Process Appendix 6 Audit Form for Acute Oncology Service
Appendix 7 Referral Pathway for Patients with MSCC
Appendix 8 Patient Pathway flow charts from ED and MAU

The purpose of this operational policy is to outline the function of the Acute Oncology Group (AOG) and the remit of the Acute Oncology Service (AOS) at Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust. The policy includes information about the current configuration of the AOS, operational procedures and referral pathways.
To ensure the Trust Board commitment to achieving its objectives in terms of cancer services and acute oncology for patients is communicated both within the organisation and to external bodies.
To ensure that systems are in place to meet national requirements and regional recommendations on acute oncology.
To ensure that comprehensive action plans are developed to enable the Trust to meet its targets and the needs of patients in relation to the AOS.
To ensure consistency of approach in how the Trust delivers the acute oncology agenda as a provider of cancer services, involving commissioners and all stakeholders of services.
To ensure that emergency care pathways are provided for patients with Neutropenic Sepsis and Metastatic Spinal Cord Compression.
To assess acute oncology patients for referral into the AOS.

To provide fast track appointments (defined as an outpatient appointment where a patient will be seen within 1 week) for patients not ill enough to need admission but needing a quicker than routine appointment.
The following two categories of patient fall under the remit of the AOS:
patients potentially suffering from the acute complications of cancer treatment e.g. neutropenic sepsis
patients potentially suffering from certain emergencies caused by the disease process itself e.g. metastatic spinal cord compression

All patients with proven cancer admitted with a cancer related complication or cancer treatment induced toxicities should be under the supervision of the AOS in conjunction with the admitting physician.
The three service areas of the AOS are:
3.3.1 Emergency Care Pathways for Neutropenic Sepsis (NS) and Metastatic Spinal Cord Compression (MSCC):
Patients with suspected/confirmed NS must receive their first dose of antibiotics within 1 hour of admission and managed as per the Trust SEPSIS 6 protocol.
Patients with MSCC must receive an MRI scan within 24 hours of admission
3.3.2 Acute Oncology Assessment Service - suitable patients will present with one or more of the symptoms listed in Appendix 3, and should be referred to the AOS within 24 hours of admission.
NB: if the patient presents OOH's and urgent advice is required please contact the on- call oncology or haematology consultant for via the Trust switchboard

3.3.3 Fast Track Appointments - defined as outpatient appointments where a patient will be seen within 1 week. These appointments are for patients who do not require admission but need a quicker than routine appointment (see Appendices 4 & 5 for fast track referral form and referral process).

Patients with a diagnosis of cancer but are admitted with an unrelated medical conditions, or with conditions not deemed best managed by an oncologist or haematologist, should remain under the care of the original admitting team.
Patients referred with malignancy of undefined primary origin (MUO) or cancer of unknown primary may be initially triaged by the AOS but will then be referred to the CUP MDT if clinically indicated
The AOG will meet twice yearly to discuss any issues relating to the Acute Oncology Service. The core members of the group will include the following:

table_items.text: Consultant Oncologists Dr S Holikova (locum consultant) Dr A Ramadan (locum consultant)
Dr T G Srinivasan (Associate specialist) & rotating staff grade

data.text: Mid Essex oncology department has 8 consultants but only  whole time oncologists* supported by 3 whole time oncology specialty doctors and x1 wte oncology SHO.

The AOS is consultant led, with support provided by specialty doctors; Oncology SHO and nurses from the chemotherapy nursing team. One named consultant has the role of lead clinician for the AOS, whose responsibilities are listed in paragraph 6.1.

*due to split site working only 2 consultants currently participate in the AOS rota. There are a number of vacancies currently and the recruitment process is on-going which will see an increase of consultant AOS participation.
Consultants' Rota

There will be a Mon- Fri morning consultant led AOS round. The team will review all patients referred to the AOS within the previous  hours. The team will provide advice and support in the management of the patient and review as indicated. Patients will remain under the care of the admitting physician.
The AOS will have x5 consultant PA's for direct patient contact and x1 SPA for AOS leadership per week.
The consultant rota can be found on the Trust intranet page http://meht-intranet/clinical-pages/acute-oncology-service-aos/
Each consultant on duty will also cover the role of MSCC Co-ordinator, whose responsibilities are listed in paragraph 6.2.

The AOS nursing support is provided from within the senior chemotherapy nursing team. One nurse will be available 5 days a week each morning to provide consultation with and/or ward visits to patients with acute oncology problems admitted during the previous 24 hours. The responsibilities of the acute oncology nurse are listed in paragraph 6.3.
*Nursing support is available Mon- Fri

Administrative staff will provide support for processing referrals and fast track clinic requests and other administrative roles. The AOS team will work closely with acute medical physicians, surgeons and the emergency department.
The responsibilities of the Lead Clinician for the AOS are:
To ensure that the objectives of the Acute Oncology Service are met
To ensure that multi-professional teams within the AOS work effectively together
To ensure care is given according to recognised guidelines, protocols and policies
To ensure clinical governance and audit are supported
To ensure that the AOS meets the peer review quality measures
To ensure the attendance levels of core members of the AOS are maintained
To prove link to the regional Acute Oncology Service Board
To lead on or nominate a lead for service improvement
To organise and chair regular meetings reviewing the functioning of the AOS, operational policies, and the training needs of the team
To ensure that service activities are audited and results documented
To ensure key policies (i.e. oncology assessment within  hours of referral, metastatic spinal cord compression pathway, and one hour antibiotic pathway for neutropenic sepsis) are implemented
To allow 1 PA in the job plan dedicated to leading the AOS
6.1.1 The AOS Lead Clinician is line-managed by the CD for Cancer & Clinical Support Services
The responsibilities of the MSCC Co-ordinator are:
Provide advice to admitting caring for patients with suspected or proven malignant spinal cord compression and who require access to the specialist supra-regional spinal oncology service
Provide a point of reference and advice for clinical teams in the management of malignant spinal cord compression
Support the provision of detailed referral information to the regional spinal centre and radiotherapy centre including patient assessment, imaging and reports
Advise that the required imaging is done promptly
Liaise with the relevant unit to ensure treatment is commenced within  hours of radiological confirmation of MSCC – where indicated
Contact local teams regarding rehabilitation issues and pain control issues
* Radiotherapy and spinal surgery are not performed at MEHT NHS Trust
6.2.1  The MSCC pathway lead is line-managed by the Clinical Lead for Oncology of the Trust, and represents the Trust at the AOS Network Board.
The responsibilities of AOS nurses are:
To ensure that advice and support are given to ward nurses regarding the care and needs of cancer patients seen by the AOS
To provide detailed clinical information about patients to the relevant clinical nurse specialist of specific tumour sites
To ensure that the community nursing team are given relevant information regarding the patient's care upon discharge by AOS
To liaise with the palliative care nursing team for patients with palliative care needs
To provide advice and support to AOS patients and their carers
To assist in nursing discharge planning for AOS patients being discharged on the same day as the AOS review
6.3.1  AOS nurses are line-managed by the Lead Chemotherapy Nurse.

Emergency Department (ED) and the Medical Admission Unit (MAU) will refer to the Acute Oncology Team if a patient has been seen who fulfils the criteria of an acute oncology presentation within one working day.
The Acute Oncology Team (AOT) will review referred patients admitted into Broomfield Hospital within  hours or referral.

The AOT will be coordinated at the Chemotherapy Day Unit. Referrals will be faxed to the chemotherapy fax number using the relevant referral form (see Appendix 1). Urgent advice can be sought form the on call Oncologist or haematologist.
Consultant bleep numbers are available on the AOS intranet page or can be found via the switchboard.
*Electronic referrals will be made via LORENZO EPR following its introduction
The AOS will meet at the Chemotherapy Day Unit at 9.00 am Mon- Fri, and will review referrals and patients admitted over the previous  hours.
The ward round will start at 09:15 hrs.
Management plans will be discussed with each relevant team and documented in each patient's notes.
Referral to other teams (e.g. haematology and palliative care) and/or MDT will take place after the ward round.

The patient pathways for AOS patients admitted via ED & MAU are shown in the flow diagrams in Appendix  Details of the different parts of the patient pathway, including AOS referral and assessment, emergency care pathways and fast track appointments are detailed in sections 8-10 below.

The AOS intranet page (see link below) contains full details consultant rotas and contact details, and downloadable versions of the AOS policies, referral forms, referral pathways and clinical documentation.
http://meht-intranet/clinical-pages/acute-oncology-service-aos/

The Acute Oncology presentations suitable for referral to the AOS are listed in Appendix  Patients who fulfil the criteria are referred using the form shown in Appendix 1, and follow the referral pathway outlined in Appendix  To make a referral:
Download the referral form from the AOS intranet page
Fill in relevant details
Fax to Chemotherapy Day Unit 01245 516081
Electronic referrals via LORENZO EPR - when introduced
8.2. Patients referred to the AOS from Monday – Friday are seen and assessed by AOS within 24 hours of referral or the next working day.
Patients referred over the weekend are seen and assessed by the team on Monday.

On occasion patients who attend the Chemotherapy day unit or day therapies unit for treatment may require an AOS review – in which case the oncology SHO will be allocated to review the patient and arrange admission if indicated.

The Trust has implemented the Sepsis 6 pathway and is committed to achieve a 1 hour antibiotic door to needle time for all patients who present with Sepsis including cancer patients with suspected/confirmed neutropenic sepsis.
Regular training on the management of Sepsis (including NS) is provided by the Trust Sepsis CNS through teaching programmes for ED, the emergency floor and ward areas.
For NS treatment guidelines and antimicrobial management please see Acute Oncology Clinical Guidelines advice sheet 15 on intranet page:
http://meht-intranet/clinical-pages/acute-oncology-service-aos/
All guidelines and treatment recommendations are subject to regular review and update by the AOS. The advice sheets can be accessed and downloaded from the AOS intranet page.
A whole spine MRI scan is undertaken within 24 hours of presentation in all patients with suspected MSCC. The referral pathway for the MRI scan is shown in Appendix

All patients presenting with MSCC have access to appropriate specialist neuro- rehabilitation to maximise function and facilitate safe and timely discharge with ongoing community rehabilitation as required. The local rehabilitation teams have been identified and contact details are listed below.
The current Trust MSCC rehabilitation contacts are:

The Trust follows the MSCC case discussion policy, namely that all cases of MSCC should, prior to definitive treatment, be subject to a case discussion. This discussion should take place as a minimum between the network MSCC clinical advisors for both the surgical oncology disciplines but may include radiology if appropriate.

The centre for surgical intervention for MSCC is based at Ipswich Hospitals NHS Trust. Radiotherapy is provided by Colchester University Hospitals Foundation Trust radiotherapy department or Southend University Hospitals Foundation Trust radiotherapy department.
The MSCC co-ordinator role is provided by the on-duty AOS consultant from Monday- Friday (excluding public holidays) from 9am – 5pm; and the on-call Oncology Consultant at all other times.

Treatment for MSCC is commenced as soon as possible, within 24 hours of radiological assessment. For MSCC treatment guidelines and care pathway please see Acute Oncology Clinical Guidelines advice sheet 12 on the AOS intranet page:
http://meht-intranet/clinical-pages/acute-oncology-service-aos/

Fast track referrals to an oncology outpatient clinic are for patients who do not require immediate admission from ED, but do need an outpatient appointment to see one of the oncology or haematology team within 7 days.
The decision to discharge oncology or haematology patients from ED should be made on the clinical judgement of senior ED medical staff.
The decision to refer oncology or haematology patient for a fast track appointment should be made by senior ED medical staff.
ED staff can discuss the patient with the on-duty AOS consultant when unsure.
Fast track referrals are made by faxing both sides of the referral form (see Appendix
4) to the Referral Centre on 01245 514869. The list of clinic codes for fast track referrals is on the second page of referral form.
No specific slot is reserved in clinics for fast track patients, but overbooking of the clinic is allowed to accommodate such referrals.
For the fast track referral pathway, see Appendix 5
The Referral Centre will telephone patients wherever possible to inform them of the date and time of their appointment, and confirm by letter.
NB: please note that these appointments are not for suspected cancer 2 ww appointments
Emergency Department (ED) and Medical Assessment Unit (MAU) communication procedure
12.1.1 The purpose of rapid communication to the AOS is to allow the prompt assessment and management input from the Service in all patients with an acute oncology presentation.
12.1.2 ED and MAU will refer to the AOS if a patient has been seen who fulfils the criteria of an acute oncology presentation (listed in Appendix 3).
12.1.3 ED or MAU will fax an AOS referral form (Appendix 1) or electronic referral to the acute oncology team within 24 hours of assessing or admitting a patient with an acute oncology presentation.

12.1.4 Urgent telephone advice from an AOS consultant can be obtained by telephoning or bleeping the on-duty consultant oncologist or haematologist. Contact details and duty roster is available on the AOS intranet page or via Trust switchboard.
Acute Oncology Service communication procedure
12.2.1 The acute oncology team will review all patients admitted or referred within the previous 24 hours or next working day with an acute oncology presentation.

12.2.2 For cancer patients known to a Trust clinical oncologist/haematologist, the patient's team will be informed of the admission. In most case the patients CNS will review the patient to offer support during the admission. From August 2017 patients will remain under the care of the admitting physician.

The acute oncology team, cancer clinical nurse specialists, lead chemotherapy nurse, medical oncology staff grade doctors, haematologist, palliative care and lead cancer nurse are notified via e-mail on Monday to Friday of all cancer patients admitted to MEHT within the last 24 hours.
Patients identified with this system should include:
Patients with a diagnosis of cancer
Patients on active anti-cancer treatments
Patients on radiation treatment
Patients who had surgery for cancer
Patients who are receiving palliative care for cancer
The list of patients in the daily e-mail includes both elective and non-elective admissions.
All patients known to oncology/haematology services will have clinic letters viewable electronically within the InfoFlex system, stating their diagnosis, treatments and treatment intention.*
*  May 2017 - LORENZO EPR to be introduced which will incorporate the function of patient letters - INFOLFLEX will continue to available for viewing only
“A cancer flagging system” that will act as an alert for ED staff when a patient is admitted on “SYMPHONY” is in place.*
*the Trust is introducing LORENZO EPR - May 2017 it is anticipated that this function will be continued following its introduction.
Consultant telephone advice is available  hours a day, 7 days a week.
Fromam topm Monday - Friday (excluding public holidays), the on-duty AOS consultant can be contacted for telephone advice.
Out-of-hours telephone advice (including evenings and weekends) is available by contacting the on-call consultant.
All contact details and duty roster are available from the AOS intranet page and the hospital switch board.
All staff will adhere to the Trust's mandatory training programme and NHSLA requirements.

In house AOS training for junior medical staff is provided by consultant and associate specialists. Medical and nursing staff will also attend conferences and courses relevant to their role as required. This will include access to AOS, access to the MSCC Co-ordinator, management of oncological emergencies, management of chemotherapy related toxicities, palliative care, symptom control and the safe prescribing and administration of cytotoxic chemotherapy.
AOS nurses undergo training relevant to their area and role, which includes:
care and administration of cytotoxic chemotherapy for the patient undergoing chemotherapy
core skills
end of life care and symptom control
Advance Care Planning
Mental Capacity Act
care of the cancer patient
training in the administration of clinical trials
education relevant to their role e.g. care of the lung cancer patient
other relevant courses appropriate to their role and place of work
The Trust will actively participate in all Acute Oncology Network Board audits.
The performance of the AOS will be monitored by collecting the following data:
Number of appropriate/inappropriate referrals into the AOS
Average time between admission and being assessed by the AOS for referred patients – target is 24hrs for referrals received Monday-Thursday, 48hrs for referrals received Friday-Sunday
Average length of stay for patients with a known or suspected new cancer who have been referred to AOS
Number of imaging requests per patient episode for patients with a known or suspected new cancer
Number of non-elective readmissions within 30 days for patients within initial admission of known or suspected new cancer
Number of appropriate/inappropriate referrals from AOS to palliative care
Time taken from admission to MRI scan for MSCC patients – target is <24 hrs
Time taken from admission to first dose of antibiotics for NS patients – target is <1 hr
30 day SACT mortality
Use of fast track referral pathway
Oncology patient length of stay
AOS data collection will be carried out daily by completing an audit form for each patient during the ward round (Appendix 6.)
*this can only take place with appropriate admin and clerical support – currently not available
MSCC Audit Requirements

16.4.1 In order to assess the timeliness of access to definitive treatment for patients that present with suspected MSCC, the NAOG will ensure audit of the pathway is adhered to. Delay in access to definitive treatment can have a significant effect on the patient's outcome. All audits will be an integral part of the member organisations' audit programmes. It will be the responsibility of the acute trust lead managers to action this.
16.4.2 For all patients who have imaging requested for a clinical suspicion of MSCC the Trust will undertake the following audits:
Time taken from the request to the imaging taking place
The type of primary investigation requested and delivered, including the proportion of patients getting MRI
16.4.3 For all patients who receive definitive treatment for MSCC (either surgery or radiotherapy) the Trust will undertake the following audits:
Time taken from the request for imaging for clinically suspected MSCC to the start of the first definitive treatment
The time from the completion of imaging to the start of definitive treatment
16.4.4 For all patients who receive definitive treatment for MSCC there should be an audit of their outcomes:
30 day mortality
Months functional outcome
Years functional outcome
Time to death
One-hour to antibiotic pathway
16.5.1 The Trust will participate in the EoE SCN audit for door to needle time in suspected NS in patient receiving SACT
16.5.2 Data on one-hour to antibiotic pathway will be collected and presented six monthly at the directorate audit meeting and to the NAOG
Breaches of operational policy and/or clinical pathways should be reported via the DATIX system. Results will be collated and reported back to the appropriate teams.
Treatment advice documents on acute oncology presentations are published on the AOS intranet page.
The Trust is committed to commit to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
References
Manual for Cancer Services: acute oncology - including metastatic spinal cord compression measures: (DOH April 2011)
National Chemotherapy Advisory Group (National Cancer Action Team 2009)
Metastatic spinal cord compression: Diagnosis and management of patients at risk of or with metastatic spinal cord compression. Full Guideline: (NICE November 2008).

Acute Oncology Referral Pathway
Patients admitted under acute medical/surgical team with conditions fulfilling Acute Oncology Referral Criteria (see below for criteria)
Download referral form from Acute Oncology Service
Intranet page.
Fax completed form to Chemotherapy Day Unit 01245 516081
Or electronic referral via LORENZO EPR (when in place)
Referred patient will be reviewed within 24 hours of referral on Monday to Friday.
Referral made late on Friday to Sunday will be reviewed on Monday.
If an oncological opinion is urgently needed, advice can be obtained over the telephone via on-call bleep. Please check on Acute Oncology Team intranet site for bleep number.
Acute Oncology Presentations
(Please see Acute Oncology clinical advice sheets on the Trust intranet)
For all known cancer patients:
Complications from systemic anticancer treatment
Neutropenic sepsis / febrile neutropenia
Chemotherapy induced nausea and vomiting
Extravasation injury
Complications associated with venous access devices
Chemotherapy induced diarrhoea
Mucositis
Hypomagnesaemia
Thromboembolic disease
Coronary spasms
Severe Thrombocytopenia
Complication from radiotherapy treatment
Acute radiation skin reaction
Radiation induced nausea and vomiting
Radiation induced severe diarrhoea
Radiation induced mucositis
Acute radiation pneumonitis
Acute cerebral / CNS oedema
Conditions caused directly by malignant disease and presenting as an urgent problem†
Pleural effusion
Pericardial effusion
Lymphangitis carcinomatosis
Superior mediastinal obstruction syndrome
Abdominal ascites
Hypercalacaemia
Malignancy spinal cord compression
Cerebral space occupying lesions
Newly diagnosed metastatic disease / recurrent disease
Severe poorly controlled pain
Pathological fracture of bone
Tumour induced visceral obstruction / blockage
Tumour induced bleeding
Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion
Brain Metastases
Any other clinical scenario where admitting team decide an urgent oncological assessment is needed.
For newly diagnosed or suspected cancer patients or unknown primary
Patients with signs and symptoms suggestive of malignant disease, requiring
Diagnostic process advice (regarding appropriate referral pathway or investigation)
Prognostic advice
Urgent oncological assessment, review and support
Conditions caused directly by malignant disease and presenting as an urgent problem (please see above†)

data.text: 7 Day Fast Track Acute Oncology ED Referral Process
Patient seen in ED suitable for discharge from ED back to primary care but need fast track oncology outpatient clinic referral.
Fill in Fast Track Clinic Referral Form (see page above) and fax referral to the MEHT Referral Centre  Details of referrals are entered into daily record log and dedicated CWT database (Somerset).

Fast Track appointment will be made to the appropriate outpatient clinic. Please tick the relevant specialty box on the reverse of the form (see page above) to ensure that the patient is booked into the correct clinic.
All 7 day Fast Track Acute Oncology ED referrals tracked by MDT office to ensure first appointment within target.
Audit form for Acute Oncology Service
